pro_critic_reviews.summary: Home Sweet Hell is a pleasantly unpleasant dark comedy, one that gives new meaning to "detached and subdivided" in the mass production zone.
Obvious and jaw-droppingly bloody, it still gives Heigl her funniest role in years.
While the oafish men come off poorly, the treatment of women as nothing more than schemers and monstrous Martha Stewart clones seems woefully past its expiration date.
A muddle of tired themes, bad behaviors and gruesome set pieces.
Although the film appears to be aiming for pitch-black humor, it’s all so mirthless that the result is genuinely ugly.
The fact that a woman has Crohn's disease is meant to be hilarious, in a nudge-nudge wink-wink "You know she's not giving her husband any sex" kind of way. It's wretched.
Dreadful, misogynist slog of a film.
A dark comedy that isn't funny and a marriage satire that doesn't break new ground.

Heigl’s performance as a coolly murderous model housewife is the only real reason to even consider watching Home Sweet Hell, an otherwise flailing and risible tale of adultery, extortion and suburban malaise that suggests a poor woman’s “Gone Girl” — one stripped of all tension, style and subtext, and instead rendered with a level of over-the-top gore that would give even David Fincher pause.
Katherine Heigl has exactly one funny moment in the dire black comedy Home Sweet Hell, which is still one more than anybody else has.
A rancid comedy fueled by male entitlement and uxoricidal rage.
The kind of blithely confident, creatively impoverished dud that leaves you slightly stunned someone greenlit it, the movie has the distinction of feeling like a bad idea from its very first frames.

user_reviews.text: Generally the idea of the movie wasn't that bad and the first quarter of the movie was actually pretty interesting. I had seen the trailer before I watched it and knew approximately what it will be about - and it was exactly what I expected after the trailer.

Home Sweet Hell is dark the script written by Carlo Allen (The Cable Guy) Ted Elrick (writer of the "Are You Afraid Of The Dark?" episodes) Tom Lavagino, they are woman haters, this film hates woman and everyone in general. This movie is more mean spirited than "Bachelorette". Katherine Heigl really must wanted a pay check, because something feels off in her performance so does Patrick Wilson. I'm not going to discuss the plot because this movie is one of the most terrible films of the year. Grade D-
Patrick Wilson showcased his acting talents much better in  A Gifted Man. Here he plays a white bread
A man's mistake fixed by his wife with a pleasure.

It wasn't as bad as people makes it out to be. The acting wasn't too bad, the script wasn't that bad either and the movie was kind of entertaining. Sure, it was downright stupid and the movie didn't make sense, but it wasn't that bad.

This movie was meh. There was great acting for Katherine Heigl & Kevin McKidd. However, it was kind of a miscast, I don't think the actors/actresses here were given the right roles for them. Finally, there was a couple funny moments, but nothing major. Low budget. Sorry but, I wouldn't recommend.

Una película bastante entretenida, aunque muy extraña. Después de una hora, dramáticamente pasa de ser una comedia divertida a una "comedia" bastante sombría. Está bien para pasar el rato, aunque las actuaciones son muy malas.
